author: nxtmonkeys

title: Spill resistant oil can bottle dipper

description.text:
I've seen these made out of tuna cans.  Put just enough oil to touch the tapered tip on the dipper.   Thus oil will not spill out if knocked over.   The lid is left loose for cleaning purposes as well as letting oil back into the can as you wipe the dipper off.  
If you want a more permanent lid,  a couple drops of super glue or hot glue will hold it in place.   Do no seal the entire lid   Oil needs to drip back into the can around the sides of the lid.  
Gluing the lid to the dipper is another way of securing it.  
Another way is to print out of ABS,  then put a little bit of acetone in the can,   Attach the lid and plug the hole with your thumb.   Shake the acetone around a bit and poor out the remainder.   Let dry for at least 15 minutes. This will seal the lid to the can.    Wear gloves and safety glasses!  
Enjoy!

Printed with .20 infill in clear ABS. 3 shells at .2mm layer height. The Simplify3d factory file is included. Prints in about 1.5 hours. Material cost $1.50 with premium ABS. Print the dipper upside down. The can and lid print as normal.
No supports required. First layer bed temp 110c
Remaining layers 90c
Extruder at 240c for clear abs

author: ark19

title: Focus Puller for Sony HDR-CX900
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I wanted cheap and cheerful way of being able to pull preset focus depths on my Sony CX900 and came up with this. There are three pieces - an 'anchor' piece which sits in front of the focus ring (where it wont move) and two 'puller' pieces which sit on the focus ring. Line up your two focal depths, holding the focal ring and sliding one of the two pullers to the appropriate position. Once set up you can go from your initial focus, to your second and third positions (the two pullers) - and then you can still pull focus back and forward between them (for example if you have two characters at different depths of field who are engaged in conversation). Watch a brief video of it in use here: http://youtu.be/OLc7UguKMm4 Note: When setting the position of the two pullers you should do so using the same pull speed as you will do when filming. If you set them by pulling very slowly between the two positions, then pull the focus quickly when filming - you may miss the desired focus. This is a limitation of this particular camera (as far as I can tell) in that if the speed of your pull is faster than the speed of the motors moving the lense it will not 'remember' the total distance your pull has travelled and so the actuall lense shift will lag behind the distance you have pulled. If anyone has some tips on how to avoid this please let me know!
This was designed in Google SketchUp.

This is kind if a modern version of the Fabergé eggs. It is small enough to hang it from a necklace a or attach it to a keyring. The egg is designed to store coins or - in an enlarged version - other objects like a car key.
The lower and the upper shell can get screwed together ( close left turn open right turn). An O-ring in the middle - printed in flexible PLA - ensures a waterproof sealing.

The egg shell is printed in ABS, the O-ring in flexible PLA.
Printing time is about 4 hours. I choose 1,5 mm shell thickness and 30% Fill Density. For € coins you can print tin 1:1 size. Using it with Swiss Francs you would need to size it 1: 1.3 or 1.4. Sizing it to the double would allow to use the egg also for larger objects like a car key you want to protect agains water.

title: monome housing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a case for a monome - well, an arduinome. It fits the spark fun button pad (available from cool components in the UK).

You could make this using either a laser cutter or a 3D router. I used some scrap MDF and a Denford 2600 3D router to make this version. There are some construction lines on the top plate DXF which can be ignored (or used?). For the the case part, you will need to set cut depth / layer up layers of laser cut stuff accordingly (to fit the thickness of the top plate material). The points are for drilling holes, I used PC stand-offs and screws to attach the button PCB to the case.

title: Bounce Adaptor for Canon Speedlite 430EX II

description.text:
Inspiration from Jolars' make for a Nikon Speedlite (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643507).
Comparison photos are bounce flash / direct flash.
The blank shot is of a white wall, area approx 5' x 5' to show the light spread. (The colour cast is due to printing my prototype for this with pink filament.)
I take my flash photos with a Canon S5is at high optical zoom (up to 20x) and minimum aperture (f8) from about 5 foot away. The indirect flash softens shadows and eliminates glare and bright spots.

title: Extruder Heater+Nozzle Assembly; Single Material Port, Two Side Air Ports (Idea 20090531)

description.text:
This is a work-in-progress (not fabricated/prototyped yet), exploring how to design a CNC/laser cuttable extruder head assembly for Makerbot/CandyFab applications.
  • Target material is 0.9mm thick steel/aluminum as provided by http://www.ponoko.com/
  • Routed channels are 1mm or 2mm wide

  • Bolt-holes are 2mm in diameter.

  • The pieces are to bolt together, then heater wire wrapped around the indented sides.
  • Material is fed from the top; air from the side ports.

  • If a magnetic material like steel is chosen for the Upper Plate, air feeds could be magnetically attached.

  • Total design height is 70mm to allow for three stages of heater-wire wrap for graduated heating temperatures.

  • Removing one or two of the stages would shorten the height by 16mm or 32mm respectively.

  • License set to Attribution - Share Alike - Creative Commons. Feel free to adapt and make money off it as long as you share your mods!

• Route or laser-cut out the individual pieces captured in the SVG files.

    • The SVG files were generated from SketchUp using the FlightOfIdeas SVG exporter plug-in.
    • See the SketchUp file to see what is cut-out versus solid.
      Center Layer x 1
       Inner Layer x 2
      Outer Layer x 2
       Upper Nozzle x 2
      ** Upper Plate x 2

  • Depending on manufacturing process artifacts, may need to grind and polish surfaces for a better seal. May need to bevel the edges in the heater-wire wrap area to prevent failure.

  • Assemble on bolts in order from outside to inside, back to outside. Check orientation at each stage to make sure pass-through overlapping points orient correctly to see through to next layer.
    3.1. Upper Plate
    3.2. Upper Nozzle
    3.3. Outer Layer
    3.4. Inner Layer
    3.5. Center Layer
    3.6. Inner Layer
    3.7. Outer Layer
    3.8. Upper Nozzle
    3.9. Upper Plate

  • Wrap heater wire.

  • Install temperature sensor(s).

  • Profile and test

title: servo gimbal (for mobius on a 250 quadcopter)

description.text:
this is a small, simple servo gimbal for my 250 quadcopter with a naze32 flight controller. the gimbal is very simple for several resons:
  • servos and m2 bolts act as supports and pivot points
  • no need for an additional gimbal controller, the signals are taken from the naze32
  • the gimbal has just two axes

• print the two supports and glue them together (two pieces since the quality of the parts is better). use the three holes for alignment
  • print the two cradles
  • test servo alignment (must be at center)
  • insert servo axle into cradle holes, secure with m2 bolt
  • slide support over the two sevos and fasten screws
    • the two servos i use are hk-15178b digital mg from hobbyking,
    the camera is fastened with rubber bands on the top cradle on top of a sheet of alpha gel if necessary.

description.text: This is my first extruder design.  It was made to use a MK8 Filament Drive.  It is for to be used for dual extrusion.

I made this with PLA with 30% fill. Some people may worry about PLA getting to hot but when you use E3D hotend the mounting side does not really even get warm. You will need the following 2 - Nema 17 stepper motors
2 - MK8 Filament Drives
2 - 625ZZ bearings (5x16x5)
4 - 3mm x 30mm socket cap screws (attaching hot ends)
4 - 3mm nylon insert lock nuts (attaching hot ends)
8 - 3mm x 6mm button head screws (attaching steppers)
3 - 4mm x 30mm socket cap screws (mounting to x-axis)
8 - 3mm x 45mm socket cap screws (holding roller to extruder)
8 - McMaster part #9657K271 springs (holding roller to extruder) http://www.mcmaster.com/#9657k271/=vovaio
8 - 3mm hex nuts (holding roller to extruder)
2 - 5mm x 16mm socket cap screws (to hold bearing into roller)
2 - 5mm nylon insert lock nuts (to hold bearing into roller)

title: Linear Bearing for a v2 RapMan

description.text:
A Y-axis bearing upgrade for a Bits From Bytes RapMan (2008 version 2)
Printing two Stanford bunnies was too much for the Y-axis :-) To replace the bearing, loosen the cornerblock bolts and slide out the bar just enough to replace the bearing. I put a short piece of 8mm rod in the cornerblock both to push the rod out and at the same time keep the loosened cornerblock stable. The length of the block is such that it can be printed on a TOM or MakerBot. If you have a larger capacity 3D printer I suggest to lengthen the block so it holds the bearing over its full length.

author: Luft

description.text: What is a Microphone Flag? When you see TV reporters walking around in the field and they have those little logo boxes on their microphones...those are mic flags. This project will allow you to print all the pieces to make a mic flag (minus the foam inserts you'll need to buy/make) for yourself.

What you'll need to complete the piece: 1 Body piece
2 Top/Bottom pieces
2 pieces of stiff foam cut to 2 3/4" x 1 3/8" x 1 1/4" You'll need the kind of stiff, but maleable, foam that you find inside Pelican and other road cases that are used to carry camera equipment and such. To assemble: fit the top/bottom pieces into body piece to make sure they fit snugly. Trim/sand as needed to make sure they fit. The stepped part should fit up inside the body piece kinda like tongue in groove. Once both pieces are fitted it should create a (relatively) smooth 3" x 3" x 2" block. Final assembly is as follows:
  • Glue either the top or bottom piece into place.
  • Fit both foam pieces into the inside of the body. When in place, they should completely fill the interior space of the flag.
  • Glue the other piece into place.
    • Once the glue is dry, you're done. You can now paint or apply stickers as needed.

remixed_from.author: davidbec08
remixed_from.title: Experimental quadruped robot with 3 jointed legs

title: UPDATED LEG FOR QUADRUPEDAL ROBOT DESIGN 583173

description.text:
The joints in the original design for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:583173 were underpowered. This experimental alternative has geared joints (1:5) and an alternative foot design for more clearance but makes use of the same servos for now (see comments in the code below). I stress: this is experimental. Will it have enough power to walk properly? There is a video of it with one geared leg working and the new foot and gears here: http://youtu.be/OPC-5zBJOzA and this is with the old foot and gears: http://youtu.be/U1ksRvyDFrg This video is just for demonstration. Later, the articulation can be broken into more steps to make the motion smoother. What you see in the video of the new foot is simply: void setup()
{
myservo_hip.attach(2);
myservo_knee.attach(3);
}
void loop() {
// HIP 90 = VERTICAL 0=FWD 180 = BACK
// KNEE 0 = VERTICAL 160 = BACK // HIP SERVO = D1501MG
// KNEE SERVO = DSS-M15S //straighten
myservo_hip.write(0); myservo_knee.write(30);
delay(syn0.5);
//strike back
myservo_hip.write(70); myservo_knee.write(0);
delay(syn);
myservo_hip.write(150); myservo_knee.write(0);
delay(syn);
myservo_hip.write(180); myservo_knee.write(150);
delay(syn);
//strike forward
myservo_hip.write(0); myservo_knee.write(160);
delay(syn1.2);
} The design is experimental because I am still working on the best compromise between the gearing and speed and it will take me some time to print enough legs to experiment properly! I haven't assembled the whole robot yet. It may still be underpowered. In the meantime, all parts for the whole 4 legged robot with current configuration are included here, along with the Rhino file, to assist in modification of this design.

I have included drawings and the Rhino file to assist in construction.   
At the moment the ankle makes use of a 100mm RC hobby car spring (around $5 each), readily available online.   
A suggested modification would be to power the foot, or to change the  gearing in the hip/knee.   
I expect I will re-design the foot in the shorter term to achieve more clearance on the forward swing.   
Any suggestions for alternative servos/design changes - anything at all - are greatly appreciated.

description.text: A frame to mount the board on the bottom

print it and use it.
Or change it. It is made with Sketchup. The source are include.

When I print a shaft parallel to the print bed (sometimes that is just the best overall orientation), the shaft is not very round. This particular instance involves a 6 mm diameter, 10 mm long shaft to hold a bearing. I need at least ten of these, so using a small file and finger held sandpaper for cleanup is not very attractive to me. I made a tool bit that I insert into a portable drill and use that to buff the axle into shape.

Print with the shaft upright, no supports, 100% fill.  
If your axle is 6 mm in diameter and 10 mm long, this will work. Otherwise, I included the 123D design file which you can modify to suit the diameter and depth needed.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Derived from Thumber's design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:485270), this remix has lower support and may be easier to print and attach as it prints in two parts, separating the backplate from the duct section. It also has an indent for a shield to prevent the slowing problem reported by some people. It uses the same turbo fan as Thurber's original.

As with the original, there is some support to remove from the inside of the duct.  I found it best to print the support in a different colour so you can see when you've got it all out.     Once printed, the duct section clicks into place just like the original and then the plate is slid down which firms up the assembly.  
Before you mount the fan and with the fan running, move it towards the back of the extruder stepper and the fan slows down.  I suspect this is due to eddy currents induced in the stepper windings causing drag.  Some people have reported a couple of sheets of ali foil solves this, but I've found a 40mm disc of steel cut from the bottom of a tin can is a lot more effective, hence the indent in the plate.   
The simplest way to power the fan is across the 24V rail, available on the 'CS-FAN' connector on the Mightyboard (clone).  However, it's not difficult to have this fan and the chassis fan run only when either of the extruder stepper fans is running which is how I've got mine.  I'll link the Instructable I'm writing here detailing this when it's finished.

description.text:
For those of us that use a 6s setup with larger props and the

have made a simple prop bumper to help stop this from happening. It mounts between the prop holder and the spinner base. You may

description.text: An improvement for Z-endstop tuning on Prusa i3 rework (from eMotion Tech).

The first part "Z_endstop_holder" is fixed on two screws of the left Z axis motor, and will support the Z endstop mechanical sensor.  
The second part "Z_endstop_tuning_screw_holder" is fixed on the lower screw of X_end_motor. It will support a M4x40mm screw, with a M4 nut inserted below and a spring. You may avoid the spring if the 4mm diameter hole is printed less than 4mm, so that the screw will thread in the plastic together with in the nut. This is another way to ensure the screw will never move after manually tuning.  
This will really ease tuning the homing position for Z axis : a quater of revolution of the screw will tune Z-home position of less than 0.2mm.
August 2016 : Added STEP files.

Here is a doubled up planetary gear bearing to hold a 24 mm diameter battery mod and 6 15 mm diameter tanks like the Kanger T3S. Overall diameter 100 mm x 40 mm tall. Created 2 100 mm diameter x 20 mm tall gear bearings (1 with gnu's script for holes in planet and 1 with emmett's original matching parameters). I then imported the stl files into sketchup stacking them on top of each other and did some cleanup and extended holes into non-hole side for more depth. This basically created a doubled up herringbone gear. I'm sure this all could have been accomplished in OpenSCAD, but my skills aren't quite there yet. Updates:
01/26/2015: Added wider base to allow for holding on edge while spinning the outer ring.
Printed with .2 mm layers, 20% rectilinear infil in Slic3r.  Took ~14.5 hours to print.

title: DJI Phantom 2 Motor Mount Skid Carbon Fiber M2 version 2 (rev 02-07-15)

description.text:
FLIGHT TEST VIDEO AT: http://youtu.be/fK3oITBfANo
Once again I have modified the left front leg mount to kick it out to the left a bit more: see m2-lft-frnt-3hole.stl. This replaces phan-mnt-m2-5deg-left-front.stl. The latter will still work for some, but I recommend using the newer one. Photos and video to follow. I added a new left front mount strut mount. Just one is used at the left front motor. It puts the strut mount and foot out of the frame on the DJI Phantom 2 Vision +, so should work for the Vision.
It will probably work with a Zen Muse, but I do not have one to test.
If someone does make one for that, and the strut is still in the FOV with a Hero, send me a photo so i can make another modification. This is an update of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:529343/#comment-554850. It would be too confusing to put all the files in the same place. There are two more mount designs here. The original was at 15 degrees to plumb. These two are at 5 degrees and 0 degrees. I have not tested them yet, so cannot say if either of them are a solution. When I get a working set I will report back, or if you beat me to it, please leave info, including your camera type and setup. Some folks may fly without a camera so it really does not matter. The compass and antenna mounts were also redesigned. The compass strut was changed to .078" (2mm) carbon fiber tube or rod. The length is flexible. The alignment of the compass is not. The compass flat face needs to be on the right rear pad with its face inboard, and parallel to the X (front/rear) and Z (up/dn) axes. The four main struts are 6.87" (~175mm) which give about 2" below a Vision plus camera pointing down. You can shorten the struts if your tolerance for risk is higher than mine. The .078 (2mm) struts for the compast is about 4" and the two for the antennas are about 3". Please leave feedback if you get it to work without intrusion of the legs into the filed of view, and what camera setup you are using. When I get time I will print and test it and post a video and results.

The other three leg mounts can be the 0 degree, or the 5 degree, your choice. 0 degree is stiffer, 5 degree absorbs more shock but may be broken more easily. You need two antenna mount struts and one compass mount strut. See the photo above (5th item). If you read the descriptions of this and the obsolete version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:529343) you will see that the left front leg can show up in the field of view when the drone yaws or rolls to the right because the camera lens is off center to the left because of gimbal balance.
Personally, I prefer the simpler http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:743731. This one looks cooler, but does not work as well, due to the FOV issue, and is more complicated.
You cannot just rename the files as far as I can see. You have to delete them and upload them again; a lengthy process.

Have you ever had a Flag Furl on your Flag pole? Problem solved with this simple product. This item is similar to these other commercially available products: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IKpf0Tl40Ss http://www.amazon.com/Valley-Forge-Flag-Diameter-Rotating/dp/B0034YXZ1A

These flag collars are designed for a 19mm diameter pole. Either Scale up or down the STL files to match you exact pole diameter or comment below on your pole diameter. I can quickly modify the Solidworks file to match your pole diameter. (Important Side note: Very important to have the STL scaled right. The fixed collar is modeled exactly at 19mm and is a snug fit on the pole. Required a small screw driver to open up the fixed collar to fit over the 19mm pole. If the fix collar is too big the Zip Ties will not hold them in place.) Print:
2 X No_Tangle_Flag_Collar_Swivel_19mm_Pole.STL
2 X No_Tangle_Flag_Collar_Fixed_19mm_Pole.STL Find:
4 X Zip Ties Use this document below on how to assemble your Fixed and Swivel Collars. Instead of using set screws use Zip ties to hold the fixed collar in place. Make sure the Head of the zip tie is facing down to avoid the flag becoming caught on it. Use the remaining zip ties to attach the flag to the Swivel collar. http://www.neverfurl.com/files/NF_Std_Instructions.pdf

title: Antenna Saver for Blade Nano QX FPV and Spektrum VA1100

description.text:
This little thing will help to save your Spektrum VA1100 antenna from bending on hard landings.  
There are 2 versions, choose the one depending on your antenna lobes alignment. If the lobe prevents installing the centered saver, choose left saver option. If your lobes are aligned to the sides and the center is free, use the centered version. My standalone Spektrum VA1100 uses left aligned saver, the one that came with Blade Nano QX FPV uses centered saver.  
It should sit tight on the pins inside, if it doesn't fit, file the bottom corners a bit.
Print with 100% infill, so that it's completely solid for strength. 0.2mm layer is recommended to better match the width.

comments.text: What is the best software to use for editing models for beginners? I like your broken in 2 pieces model, but sideways holes always come out crappy for me. I want to just make that part solid and I will just drill it out after printing.  I'm having a heck of a time trying to figure out how to do that though. Thanks for any help.
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: You will need to find a piece of software that can take an STL file and turn it back into a solid. FreeCAD will do it, but there are also a couple of commercial applications also. A better choice would be to take your time and really do a thorough calibration, round holes should end up round whether they are printed flat or on edge. If they are not it would indicate that your printer is not properly calibrated.
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: Used SLS method so that's why there are no support structures. My best guess is that you have two options. if you print it on its side then both tabs will need support, if you print it leaning from back to front, you will need to support it up to the mounting tabs. The other way to print it would be if using ABS print in two pieces with the mount tabs separate but on a 15.4 mm square base and a corresponding notch in the case. Then use a few drops of Acetone to weld the two pieces together.
comments.author: WheresWaldo

comments.text: how did you print this? (what direction)
comments.author: TV3master

comments.text: Try it as two pieces, I added a file that breaks it apart. Using ABS, a few drops of Acetone will weld the pieces together. You won't need to add any support structures if they are printed separately, and you will also have the option to orient the GoPro tabs perpendicular to the mount if you need to.

title: Spider coupling - 5mm axis to M8 drivescrew

description.text:
This is a printable spidercoupling. It connects a stepper with a 5mm axis to an M8 drive screw. Both parts are uploaded below as separate STL-files.
You will need 4 M3x10 bolts + nuts to finish the part. This thing is part of a design for a small CNC milling machine.
More details can be found at http://www.repairablemachines.com

-Print the 2 halves
-put in 2 M3 nuts in each piece
-screw in the M3 bolts, but not all the way. Make sure they catch on the nuts
-place the halves on the axis/screw and fix by tightening the bolts.

author: lievenstandaert

description.text:
The zipper pull tab on my coat broke, so why not print a new one.  I'm not sure this will last for very long, but we'll see.  I created two parts - zipperb2 will feed through the hole in the slider, then it can be glued to part zippera to close it and complete the tab.  This was a hair thick for my coat, but I did manage to feed it through after a slight rub with 180 grit sandpaper.  
1/26/15 update:  This is working so far for me, but the connection between the two pieces is a weak spot likely prone to breakage - with a good cyanoacrylate soak, it is holding, but I will likely redesign the two parts for an eventual replacement.  
1/28/15 update:  The printed replacement is still holding, but I've uploaded a redesign for trial the next time.  Anyone who wants to try it, please give feedback.  I've switched to a pin and socket design, so your printer will need to be able to handle very small overhangs, but there is room around the pins to handle a tiny bit of sag in the overhangs and also to allow application of cyanoacrylate to hold the two pieces together.  The new design is zippertaba and zippertabb - the zipperassembled shows the completed assembly.

These simple inserts go over standard FESTOOL clamps to reduce the appearance of dents when using the clamps directly on wooden surfaces.  
The STL file labeled as "with Supports" is slightly longer with tapered supports to enable your FESTOOL clamp to sit straight up and down, which is helpful for some clamping applications. I also tightened up the tolerances slightly with this file so its a little tighter fit. Adjust as you like.
Print, insert, enjoy.

title: Waves within Waves within a Wave Fractal

description.text: This is a fractal design that I wrote the program for as part of FYS 108, a course on chaotic dynamics and fractal geometry at Centre College. It was printed on Form1+. From a certain distance away, this fractal reminds me of waves building on top of each other chaotically. However from up close its many layers suggest to me a sort of cliff face, jutting out into the sea and eroded by centuries of crashing waves. I like this Fractal in particular because it reminds me of the universality of Fractal Patterns.

author: Shain_Mays

description.text:
• FlashForge Dreamer (right and left side)
  • Dremel 3D Idea Builder
    • The OmniStand is a quick connect adjustable filament spool stand for the FlashForge Dreamer and Dremel 3D Idea Builder printers. The OmniStand replaces the filament stand that comes with these 3D printers. The stand allows many different sizes of filament spools to be used on both the right and left sides of the printer (note: the Dremel 3D Idea Builder only has a single printer stand on the left side). Optional non-quick connect OmniStand compatible stands are found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675309. These non-quick connect single piece stands work with the same filament rods and spacers the quick connect stands work with. However, the newer redesigned type B quick connect stands are easily replaced and have less sag than the single piece designs, making them obsolete.

Three filament rod hole positions are optimized for 3 different filament spool size categories: up to 184x65 mm (7.24x2.55"), up to 230x65mm (9.05x2.55"), and up to 190x77 mm (7.48x3.03"). For slightly wider spools see here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667473 Using the 100 mm filament spool rod the stand was tested to fit the following filament spools inside the FlashForge Dreamer and Dremel 3D Idea Builder:
  • ASAPTech TPE (0.7 kg white tested)
  • ColorFabb (0.75 kg CopperFill tested)
  • Dremel (all filament tested)
  • ESun (0.5 kg bronze tested)
  • Filamex (0.5 kg spools of ABS/PLA tested)
  • FlashForge Dreamer (all filament tested)
  • Hatchbox (1 kg and 0.45 kg spools of ABS/PLA tested)
  • Magic Cube (0.45 kg ABS tested)
  • MakerBot (0.5 lbs small spool of PLA tested)
  • MG Chemicals (0.25 kg of PLA/ABS tested)
  • NinjaFlex (0.5 kg Fire color tested)
  • Taulman (0.45 kg of T-glase tested)
  • USAFilament (0.5 kg PVA tested)
  • Zen Toolworks (1 kg wood filament tested, others might not fit)
    • Filament spools tested that cannot fit inside the FlashForge Dreamer or Dremel 3D Idea Builder:
  • Filament Outlet (1 kg spool of HIPS tested)
  • Gizmo Dorks (1 kg spool of HIPS tested)
  • MakerBot (2 lbs large spool of PLA tested)
  • Octave (1 kg spool tested)
  • Shaxon (1 kg spool of ABS tested)
  • USAFilament (1 kg spool tested)
    • Note that these filament spools do however fit the OmniStand Top Mount Filament Spool Stand for use outside the printer.

The base of the stand mounts directly in place of the FlashForge Dreamer or Dremel 3D Idea Builder's original filament stand. It mounts to the bottom using the original filament stand holes and screws. No additional hardware is needed.  
The base of the stand has a unique sturdy quick connect design, allowing different stands to be easily exchanged without unscrewing anything. This allows different stand designs to be inserted into the stand base, without the need for screws.

New to version 1.34, type B quick connect stands offer greatly increased sag reduction (See version update notes below) under heavy filament load. They are recommended over the original stand when using filament heavier than 0.5 kg. The original spool stands are now found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675350 The quick connect stands have a sliding switch with two positions. The switch is designed to move easily, and snaps into either the locked, or unlocked position. When switched down, the switch locks the stand into the base. When switched up, the stand can be easily removed from the base by sliding it towards the center of the printer. Two quick connect filament stands are included. One for the left side and one for the right side. Either stand can connect to any base. Each quick connect stand has three rod holes to allow the filament rod to better accommodate different sized filament spools. The bottom rod hole is specifically designed to fit FlashForge Dreamer and Dremel filament spools allowing them to go down into the filament depression at the bottom of the printer, maximizing clearance space in the printer. Other filament spools up to 184x65 mm should fit, but some spools might require an additional spacer for the spool's hole. The middle rod hole is designed for filament spools that are thin enough to fit into the filament depression at the bottom of the printer, but too large to fit the standard FlashForge Dreamer and Dremel filament stand. Spools up to 230x65mm should fit, but some rolls might require an additional spacer for the spool's hole. The top rod hole is designed for filament spools that are too fat to fit into the filament depression at the bottom of the printer. Spools up to 190x77 mm should fit (or 190x82.5 mm if using the maximum length rod found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667473), but some spools might require an additional spacer for the spool's hole.

The filament rods are 19 mm (0.74") in diameter, and made to accommodate 20 mm (0.78") filament spool holes. Some spools will fit better if a spacer is used. This set includes 6 filament rod spacers.
  • 77x24 mm (3.03x0.94")
  • 77x29 mm (3.03x1.14")
  • 77x34 mm (3.03x1.33")
  • 77x39 mm (3.03x1.53")
  • 77x44 mm (3.03x1.73")
  • 77x49 mm (3.03x1.92")
    • The filament rod spacers slip over the filament rods and expand the rods to 24 mm, 29 mm, 34 mm, 39 mm, 44 mm, and 49 mm in diameter to accommodate filament spool holes over 50 mm in diameter. The 39 mm, 44 mm, and 49 mm spacers have a 5x2 mm lip on them to keep the spool in place, so they reduce the rod's spool width capacity by 2 mm. The spacers fit the recommended 100 mm long filament rod.

The filament rods are compatible with the FlashForge Dreamer and Dremel 3D Idea Builder filament rods. They use the same connector design, are the same diameter, but are much longer. The set includes 1 spool rod size. The 100 mm long rod fits on either the left or right side. It can hold spools that are 77 mm wide. It is recommended to use this rod as the standard rod. It has a good amount of clearance from the build plate. Heavy spools of filament will not cause problems with this rod. Additional extra long rods are found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667473
OmniStand Extra Long Filament Spool Rods OmniStand Top Mount Filament Spool Stand Non-Quick Connect OmniStand Compatible Filament Spool Stands OmniStand Compatible Quick Connect Filament Spool Stands

Note that the two FlashForge Dreamer and Dremel 3D Idea Builder filament depressions on the bottom of the printer are only 66 mm wide, and should only be used for filament spools that are 65 mm wide or less. Filament spools that are wider than 65 mm should not go into the filament depression, and should therefor use the top filament spool hole.

1.36 - 3/1/2015, Updated the feet of Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B to match the improved foot design of Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B-Right. 1.35 - 2/9/2015, Moved the old quick connect stands to their own location here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675350. Also moved the now obsolete non-quick connect single piece stands to their own location here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675309 1.34 - 2/8/2015, Added new type B quick connect stands: Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B and Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B-Right. These improved type B quick connect stands connect to the existing OmniStand quick connect base. The new stands have an extended base that has a slight downwards slope, which helps prevent the stand from bending in towards the build plate. With these type B stands printed at 70% infill using ABS plastic, I measured a 5 mm reduction in sag at the end of the 100 mm filament rod holding a 1 kg roll of filament. It's recommended to switch to using these new quick connect stands if you are using filament heavier than 0.5 kg. 1.33 - 2/7/2015, Fixed minor issues found in the mesh for the STL files Dreamer-Spool-Stand-Single-Right, and Dreamer-Spool-Stand-Single, which could cause problems for some slicers. 1.32 - 2/4/2015, Moved the extra long filament spool rods to their own Thingiverse page found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667473 1.31 - 1/31/2015, Modified 34, 39, 44, and 49 mm spacers to print with less plastic. 1.3 - 1/30/2015, Added Dreamer-Spool-Stand-Single-Right.stl, which is a single piece version of the standard 3 hole stand with the bend for installing on the the right side of the printer. In this version the stand base is part of the stand, making the stand slightly more study, with a loss of modularity of course. I also had to make the stand a little thinner to allow access for one of the screw holes. 1.2 - 1/29/2015, Added Dreamer-Spool-Stand-Single.stl, which is a single piece version of the standard 3 hole stand. In this version the stand base is part of the stand, making the stand slightly more study, with a loss of modularity of course. 1.1 - 1/27/2015, Added 100 mm filament spool rod and rod spacers.

I printed and tested all of my parts using Filamex White ABS. Others have used PLA. For the Dremel printer, PLA should be fine. For the Dreamer with the heated build plate, ABS should probably be used.

Except for the filament spool rod spacers, print all other parts at 0.10 mm layer height, no thicker, to ensure a proper fit of all parts.  
The base prints without support. Print it with the large flat side down. Use 70% infill and 3 shells.  
The stands require support for overhangs in back of the rod holes only. The portion where the stand lock is inserted should not be printed with support. The stand should be printed with it's long flat side down (it's back), and not standing up, otherwise the rod holes will not print correctly. Use 70% infill and 3 shells.  
The filament spool rod requires support at the very top where it locks into the stand's rod holes. The rod must be printed standing upright. If printed on it's side, it will be rough, require much more support, and might not fit into the stand properly because of warpage. Use 70% infill, and 3 shells.  
The stand lock switch prints without support. Print it with the large flat side down. Use at least 20% infill and 3 shells.  
The filament spool rod spacers should be printed standing upright. These do not need to be strong. I recommend printing them with at least 2 shells, and around 10% infill.

description.header: INSTALLATION  OF THE QUICK CONNECT STANDS
description.text: Step 1: print Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B-Right.stl for the right side of the printer and Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B.stl for the left side of the printer. Installation is the same for both stands. Step 2: remove the bottom of the FlashForge Dreamer or Dremel 3D Idea Builder. Be aware that these printers' filament stand's nuts are located under the printer's body directly under the filament stand, and the nuts will fall off once the filament stand is unscrewed. Carefully unscrew and remove the original filament stand, being careful not to lose the nuts that come off. It's advised to do this work in a location where the nuts will not be easily lost if they fall off and bounce away. Using the original stand screws, attach the printed stand base securely in the same location the original stand was installed. Step 3: insert the lock into the stand so that it snaps in. Once the lock snaps into the stand it will not come back out. The lock works as a switch with 2 positions: locked, and unlocked. When in the unlocked position, the switch's end is completely inside the stand. When in the locked position, the switch's end extends down below the stand's bottom. Step 4: switch the stand's lock into the unlock position and slide the stand into the stand base. Step 5: switch the stand's lock into the lock position by sliding the switch down into the stand base. The stand is now securely attached to the stand base and will not come out as long as the switch is in the locked position. Step 6: insert the rod into your chosen filament spool, and attach the rod to the filament stand. Insert the rod with the handle level to the bottom of the printer. To lock the rod in the stand, turn the rod counter clockwise so that the handle is perpendicular to the bottom of the Dreamer.

comments.text: Today, I improved the set by adding new type B quick connect stands: Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B and Dreamer-Spool-Stand-B-Right. These improved type B quick connect stands connect directly to the old OmniStand quick connect base without the need for any tools. The new stands have an extended base that has a very slight downwards slope, which helps prevent the stand from bending in towards the build plate.  This new design also helps stabilize the quick connect joint, by reducing joint play. With these stands printed at 70% infill using ABS plastic, I measured a 5 mm reduction in sag at the end of the 100 mm filament rod holding a 1 kg roll of filament.
comments.author: BaronWilliams

comments.text: The 100 mm filament spool rod in this set has good clearance. I have been using it exclusively without any issues for dozens of prints. The potentially problematic 103 and 105.5 mm rods that were previously part of this set have been removed from this set and are now in their own location on Thingiverse found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667473

title: DJI Phantom 2 Vision Plus Prop Guard

description.text:
This is a remake of Sockles Prop Guards.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316762 The file was modified to fit the small screw on the front.
I also made the prop guards more light weight and aerodynamic, while keeping the strength. Print with Raft and Supports as one side is smaller then the other for airflow. The part is also radiused on the bottom.
Mounts underneath prop arm with two M3-.5 x 12 screws. I added the .IGS and .STP files for this so you can modify it if you please. This was designed and rendered with CATIA V5 R21 If you feel inclined to tip, please send Bitcoins to 1eJBKpUE2MoWDWCgCVimuZfuRzLqQFxM8 Disclaimer -- I will not be held responsible for anything that YOU do after DL'ing and printing this Thing. Propellers can and will strike any object located to the side and above propeller. Disclaimer

Download the prop guard Open in your favorite printing program.
Align object in slicing program to be rotated 45* degrees. You will need a printer with a print bead of a 200mmx200mm build area or bigger to print this part (make sure to align it in your program to print in the center of your build plate, you are cutting it very close to the extends) You are going to need a total of 8 M3-.5x12 socket cap screws. Two screws for each propeller. I used (low profile heads) to keep consistency with the other screws on the quad. Print with PLA or ABS. I suggest to make them solid but you can play around with the infill. Print with a raft and support as the bottom has a radius on it and the inside lip of the prop guard is slightly smaller then the outer lip. Clean up raft and support, unscrew the first 2 screws and attach to the drone. P.S. these are useful for flying in places with unstable ground to land. Sometimes the drone will tip if the ground is uneven, These will save your props. It will not however save your from trees or slamming it into any hard surface. Use at your own Risk

description.text: Every electronic device seems to have that little keyhole in the back that defies the ability to get an exact line up with a couple of screws ( which have to be just the right size head and that is naturally smaller than everything you have).  This is my solution.  slip one of these in each keyhole on the device, place a drop of superglue on the back of each and press the device up to the wall.  For lightweight devices, that is all that need be done.  For heavier, a small flat head screw can be used but make sure it doesn't stick up above the top of the hole.  Do NOT hang heavy items with these.  The ABS plastic is only 3.5 mm wide at the stem.

cura sliced

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/89grnLtY1Xs

I studied with Ann Hamilton at UCSB in the late 80's and I have always loved this picture of her by Bob DeBris from that time. I actually set out this morning to try to model the whole image of her but had problems with the hands and the head of twitches. I decided to pull it back to a simpler object so that's how I happened upon the idea of just making it a vase for dry grasses.   
I have not poured water into it and I am sure it would hold liquid but I am worried it would tip over. I thought the feet were totally flat but it tends to lean back so I just sanded down the front soles a little. I also painted the exposed legs with an off-white nail polish.
This thing is used to keep your phone charging cables from falling to the floor and becoming a tangled mess. I have also included the .ipt file so that you can edit it in AutoDesk Inventor.
Apply double sided tape to the back and place it on the side of your night table...or wherever you would like!

Because the continuous miniaturization this world is immerse in, I got a lot of empty space in the medium AquaBox I use to hold the GPS to the motorbike when I upgraded to an iPod with an external GPS antenna.
So I decided to fill the empty space with several plastic pieces intended to hold everything in its place. I know that this is not very useful for the rich men out there since there are AquaBox models for this purpose and the correct sizing, but we are talking about recycling, and nights of entertainment with the 3D modeler, awaiting for my printer to come, figuring all the problems that could appear and continuously modifying the design, just waiting for that magical first print that everyone talks about.
Print, screw following the v5 image, mount and ride! Almost all the screws go through (and are hold by) the plastic. For the rest of them use nuts.

comments.text: Some things I've learned while building:
comments.author: ssshake

comments.text:
Printing well at 60%, for 1/4" BBs. Except for the way Cura (13.06.5) slices it. While infilling the spiral, Cura for some reason makes a lot of unnecessary travels in a row. It doesn't retract, so the extruder oozes, which makes it "un-primed" for the next time it actually has to infill something. So there are crappy not-well-filled sections of the solid infill.
Slic3r completely ignores the spiral, which is strange. It slices everything else in the plate. But not the spiral.

description.text: This birdhouse is really large and requires a printer with a minimum build height of 186 mm (7.35 in), although the bed can be the standard 200 X 200 mm.

I printed this in ABS and Bridge Nylon on a modified Prusa i3 that has a 230mm (9in) build height. Sliced with 1mm layers, 15% honeycomb infill, 30mm/sec perimeter speed. No support was required with these print settings.
The entry hole is filled to prevent warping and layer separation, just cut this single layer out with an Xacto or similar knife. Print one birdhouse, one birdhouse top, and two dowel clips in ABS. Print the bail in Nylon for a sturdier, more flexible piece. A 1/4in dowel is used to secure the top to the house and the clips keep the dowel from drifting.

comments.text: @rspraggjr, Yes the hole is filled in, but it is a single layer thick so that it can be easily removed. This had to be done to minimize layer separation when printing that segment of the birdhouse. Sorry I forgot to mention that in the instructions.

description.text: I was getting annoyed when the filament tube was getting kinked every time it passed under the top cover near the rear of the my creatr bed so I designed this guide to stop it getting kinked.

I used PLA with a layer height of 0.3mm and bed temp of 50 degree C. Since the part is so small I printed it solid and with a brim of 3mm to help it stick to the bed and not curl up at the edges. 
When you're placing it on your bed for slicing in Repetier make sure to rotate it 180 degrees about the y-axis so its facing the correct way up!

comments.text:
The friction is actually quite OK. The teflon tube runs all the way through the filament guide and sticks out on the bottom through the aluminum plate.
The original design has the teflon tube just sticking though the aluminum plate resulting in sharper bents.
Since this guide guides the teflon tube in a better way, the teflon tube will stay straight with bigger bents actually resulting in less friction thgouth the whole tube.

Here is a fan shroud you can screw on the 20x20mm Fan of the BI 2.5.
Simply use the 2 un-used holes of the fan to install. I suggest using M4 plastite screw but a M4 machine screw with nut would also work.

Housing to suit a reprap full graphic display.  Mounts to the printer using 4 x M5 cap scews.  When mounted the display will be on a 45º angle to make viewing easy.  
The front cover is help on with 2 x M3 x 16mm cap screws and nuts and 2 x M3 x 25 cap screws.

The screw mounting posts on the rear cover have been made deliberately longer to suit variations in board heights.  Just trim them down to suit your board.   It seems not all the the boards are made the same.  
The top posts are to be tapped with an M3 tap to enable the M3 x 25 cap screws to screw in.  The M3 nusts just press into the recesses in the rear cover.

description.text:
Inspiration for this customizable thing was taken from these 3 things: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:579033
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:606224
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:569241 With my thing you can customize the number of "lines" and "columns" your bin will take on your case and also customize the number of horizontal and vertical dividers inside your bin. You can also choose if you have the "Shallow" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00005QWYF/) or the "Deep" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001G1CUK0/) organizer. Please note that I do not have the deep organizer so I derived the height from the STL of one of the things I mentioned above. Let me know if I have the wrong height and I'll update my code.

I'm using 2 top and bottom solid layers, 4 perimeter shells, 25% infill and 0.3mm layer height. You need to print with support due to the small feet. Update: With the new version you can choose to print as 2 separate parts that will need to be glued together but that DO NOT need support. Thanks @chrismolloy for the suggestion.

This box was designed based on the dimensions of the LCD I got with my arduino startup box back in the day, please make sure the dimensions fit your LCD before you print this as other Chinese LCDs seem to be smaller in dimension of the frame. the LCD frame that this was designed around is 71.5x27.2 mm.

title: walking egg

description.text:
3D printed slope walker
Shade 3D Professtional ver.14.1.2
Afinia H480 (ABS)
http://youtu.be/HVPlPhdjhM0

• 1 x WE_body.stl
  • 1 x WE_shaft.stl
  • 1 x WE_leg.stl

Please use a rigid slope with high friction surface (ex. cork board).
Please adjust the angle of the slope for a better walking.
In my case, "egg" can walk at 5 - 8 degree.
Suitable slope angle is dependent on the condition of "egg" and slope.

• Does "egg" rotate freely its rear leg?
  • Does "egg" have smooth sole?
  • Does "egg" stand on its rear leg on the horizontal plane?
  • Does "egg" stand on its rear leg on the slope?
    • Please decrease the slope angle, if "egg" rolled forward.
    • Please increase the slope angle, if "egg" fell on its behind.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:977519 It is far superior to this design!

Edit 6/18: I have successfully modeled and tested the clip for the new version! This might not sound like much but the clip is probably harder than the rest of it.  This project is officially being processed!

Edit 6/5: I have been quite busy and the new version hasn't left the paper (better than just idea right?).  It is next in the design queue however, so when I get some time I'll try to work on it.  I hope to finish it by August of this year, but that is a loose date.
Edit 3/15: A new version is in the works and is expected to be completed in a month from now unless I get bogged down with other work.  (I want to finish in time for next month's match)

Edit 2/12: This has been tested and the clip is extremely difficult to insert, although with enough filing it works.  The spring is also very stiff, so a less stiff spring will be available soon.  It does have very nice retention, however.  
I have concluded that I could get away with much less plastic in the body (I'm not a ME by trade give me a break) so I think a major overhaul is in order :|  
Print with less infill or wait, I'd recommend just printing with less infill.

I needed some decent mag pouches for competitions and I've seen other designs on Thingiverse, but non of them were implemented with a spring clip like other commercial designs do.  This should hold anything shaped like a Glock magazine, and I tried to make it short enough that it could accomodate a Glock 19/23 size mag as well as the full size ones.  It might fit a 26 size mag too.

Print with 100% infill in PLA or something rigid:

  • GMH_Body.stl

    • If desired, print with any desired amount of infill in either PLA/ABS:
    GMH_MagGuide.stl //guides mag into holster (optional) Print the following with 100% infill in ABS or something with some give to it:

  • GMH_Plate.stl
    GMH_SpringBETA.stl //more retention levels coming soon!
    and either:
    GMH_Clip.stl //smaller clip for normal belts
    -or-
    GMH_Clip5.11.stl //bigger clip for 5.11 Tactical's reinforced Operator belt

    Once all parts are printed, assemble them as pictured, putting the plate on the bottom last. When other springs are released, the funny shaped hole in the bottom of the plate allows a large diameter flathead screwdriver to be used to push a new spring into its slot. The bottom plate is supposed to fit tightly, so this makes changing out retention springs easier (at least that was my intention.) Also you will notice the hopefully poorly attached piece of plastic in the body where the clip goes in, this was to avoid printing with supports and has been sufficient so far.

title: Pogo pin debug jig for Hubsan Q4 / Estes Proto-X micro quadcopters

description.text: Jig to solderlessly attach to the CPU debug pins of the Hubsan Q4 or Estes Proto-X quadcopters for hacking. Useful for working with bradwii firmware. My Proto-X looks like it has a conformal coating over both side of the board, including the test points. But that doesn't seem to stop the sharp conical point pogo pins from making contact and talking with the debugger. Update: WIP Bradwii port to Q4 / Proto-X here. Sort-of works, needs some minor fixes and PID tuning. Contributions welcome!

Parts: -Sparkfun pointed tip pogo pin - other tips would work too. Order at https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9174 . Will need serious tweaking to use with pogo pins of different lengths and diameters. -Small gauge wire of some sort. I used a CDROM audio cable from the junk bin since it has 26ga stranded wire and terminates in Dupont socket pins which fits my SWD adapter nicely. -An SWD JTAG adapter. I use the STLINK/V2 adapter since I have a devkit with one built in and it's supported in OpenOCD. -Rubber band or velcro cable tie to hold the copter in the jig Pins: swclk - "C" on the board - SWD clock
swdio - "D" on the board - SWD data
gnd - unlabeled pad on the board - system ground
vcc - "+" on the board - 3.3V from after the regulator Construction: The pogo pin holes are narrower at the ends to make it easy to ream them to size with a hobby knife. Enlarge both ends so the pogo pin fits snugly. Be careful with forcing the pin in as they snap easily. Solder the leads to the 3mm of the pin body near the plunger, making sure not to let solder reflow onto the plunger. Use: If debugging while running on battery power, omit vcc. There's a chance of shorting the battery while loading the copter into the jig, so consider using vcc and detaching the battery first. At a minimum, don't plug the copter in while either end is powered up. These pins have some play in the plunger, so check that the tips are on the pads before powering up the target.

title: No Tie Paracord Cam Lock with Hook

description.text: Easy to use, non-slip grip, simple to print. Use this to grip paracord without having to tie a knot. I really like the paracord ratchet (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23562 ) but I wanted to design a simpler alternative so this is what I came up with. Paracord on Amazon: http://amzn.to/1gIiqlo Video link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YqImNL67kf0&feature=youtu.be

There are three part files but you will only need two. You have the option of printing the cam with or without the hook. I recommend printing this baby thick so you can count on it holding up with the paracord's rated load. Maybe 40% hexagonal infill. Fastener:
(1) 1.25"~1.5" long 10-24 bolt
(1) 10-24 nylock nut
5/32" dia 550 paracord
